doc.after: Following one of the other meanings of the word, Aristotle, in the Ars Rhetorica, gave logos a different technical definition as argument from reason, one of the three modes of persuasion (the other two modes are pathos (Greek: ÏÎ¬Î¸Î¿Ï), persuasion by means of emotional appeal: "putting the hearer into a certain frame of mind",[24] and ethos (á¼¦Î¸Î¿Ï), persuasion through convincing listeners of one's "moral character.")[24] According to Aristotle, logos relates to "the speech itself, in so far as it proves or seems to prove."[24][25] In the words of Paul Rahe:
